generation: Another week flew by. Yesterday, I drove past the new house and noticed the front window covered in boxes. We might get the keys at closing—I’m thrilled! If everything goes smoothly, we’ll close a week from Wednesday. Last night, Bethany and I stayed up past 3:00am watching movies. Lately, we’ve been binge-watching quite a bit. Here’s the rundown: we saw *Thirteen*, a must-watch for mothers of teens—better than expected. Then we watched *Gigli*—just as bad as the reviews claimed, but we had to see for ourselves.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone full of repeats, but now there are two great new shows, and I’ve been watching both religiously. *Blow Out*—the gayest concept ever with seemingly zero gay people in sight—follows hairstylist Jonathan Antin as he tries to open a second location of his popular West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Normally, I wouldn’t care, but while flipping channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan—equally narcissistic and dull—staring at an empty space on Rodeo Drive, declaring (loudly), "I’m going to build the greatest salon in the history of the world!" And I was hooked. Not since *Rocco* have I found such a moron so compelling to watch.

What a week... My right shoulder has tendonitis, right under the shoulder blade. Moving my arm too much—especially while using a computer mouse—is agonizing. I overdid it while updating my website and handling other online tasks, so now I can barely move it. Finding the energy to draw feels impossible, and lack of sleep worsens the pain. I’m not at my best, but I’ll recover. On a brighter note, my mom’s surgery went well. Her eyesight has improved slightly—she can distinguish fuzzy shapes and colors—though she remains mostly blind. Here’s hoping her vision fully returns soon.

Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest tasks can become an ordeal. I also discovered how incredibly kind strangers can be, simply because they choose to be. Trust me, it wasn’t about ulterior motives—I had kid drool all over me and was in my 'wash-day' attire. Besides, I’m not entirely sure I’ll ever bathe again, so there wasn’t even an olfactory incentive! Right now, I’m doing two things: composing a post and watching No Doubt’s music videos, all from my desk.

It's 11:14 PM MST, and here I sit in my bedroom repairing the personnel director's computer from work. I don't mind helping, but I often wonder how frequently I end up fixing someone else's device as a favor. While I'm happy to serve people this way, where do we draw the line between kindness and being taken advantage of? Lately, I've been staying up late reading, so I was eager to sleep early—until I realized it'd be better to return this computer sooner rather than later. *laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So tonight, I'm rewatching *Joe Schmo 2*.

If they’re unwilling to do so, I’d prefer they just stay in bed and drift into eternal sleep. I’m utterly exhausted by foolishness. Now, I’m not the sharpest tool in the shed, but I’m not discussing complex matters—just basic reasoning. So, I believe it’s fair to criticize the senselessly dim-witted. Let’s focus on a few specific types today and save the rest for another time. Sound good? Great.

Went to The Cove to see Supernothing—they were great as always, and got to hang out with Tiago. Saturday: worked, then went out with Joe and Rach; met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. Got home around 11:45 PM and woke up at 6:45 AM for a meet. Arrived a bit late, but it went well—full routine on floor (no falls!), second on floor and vault, third on beam. Scored 29.45 all-around, which isn’t bad since I improve as the season progresses.

Have you ever had one of those moments when you start reflecting on life? Like sitting in math class, utterly bored, and wondering how your brain even processes math? Then it hits you—you exist, you're in math class, and you question why. Suddenly, you marvel at how incredible existence is, only to realize how absurd this train of thought is. Ever experienced that? I despise it. And you know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who thought sitting through a two-and-a-half-hour class was a good idea? It’s pure torture.

I believe Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow never to touch that cursed iron piece (not the hot one, the game token) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few dollars and won the damned game—or perhaps I let him win since he’s leaving soon, and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However the story goes, it pales in comparison to this Texas-sized headache I have now. I’ve taken some Aleve, and it’s helping, but all I need is some well-deserved rest. *Your telephone’s the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck...* —At the Drive-In

Well... Today has been a long day. We drove home from Indiana, and I’ll need to be selective about what I write since I don’t have much energy. First, camp was incredible—even better than I expected. God has been working in my life lately, and it’s been amazing. I’ve turned over a new leaf, but back to the start. We arrived at the Twiggs’ house Friday evening and stayed until leaving for camp on Monday. Most of our time was spent at the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watching movies.

Today is my last day of summer vacation! Ugh, and I have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate it, but I’d rather get it over with than reschedule during my surgery rotation. I’m nervous, scared, jittery—basically every synonym for 'I really don’t want to go' to school. This will be a whole new challenge for me. As a perfectionist, I love excelling at everything I do, but starting new things is tough. I hate being a pawn (like I told Cassie: 'I’ll be the only pawn insisting on moving like a knight'), and I hate feeling clueless.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned, as early as 1996, about the looming threat of a 'third Islamic state' emerging in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, former head of the Intelligence Bureau and now Uttar Pradesh's Governor, predicted this grave danger in a series of articles published in *The Hindustan Times* back in 1996. Shourie poses a pertinent question: Does knowing that Rajeswar—not him or Mr. Advani—wrote these warnings lend them credibility? Or does it imply that Rajeswar is a closet communalist, unfit to remain Governor?

For the past two days, I’ve been overwhelmed by terrible exhaustion—bone-deep fatigue. Last evening, I went home and slept immediately, only waking when my mother called around 8:30. When I opened my eyes, it was pitch dark—I hadn’t turned on the lights—so for a moment, I couldn’t tell the time or date. There was just my mother’s voice in the darkness as I struggled to grasp reality. I wonder why I’m so drained... Lovely weather this morning—it was drizzling when I arrived. Though I hear it’s been raining in Calcutta for three days.

Last night was terrible. I discarded the sweater I was knitting after completing only 14 inches. I lost around $10 worth of yarn (at $8 per skein). By the time I reached the armholes, there were too many stitches, and the mohair kept tangling as I worked. Frogging was ineffective—the yarn kept breaking. Uncharacteristically, I didn’t swear. I just gloomily ripped rows while listening to *Sex and the City* (thanks, library!). Eventually, I gave up and tossed it. At least I learned a lot from this attempt.

Last night in class, we discussed the week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World* by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement," while the second examines "displacement." Casey argues that modern culture prioritizes time as the organizing force—evident in phrases like "running out of time" or "saved time." He proposes that centering culture around place fosters a more grounded community. (This is a rough summary—disclaimer in case my professor or classmates read this.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly captivated me.

Whatever they put into freeze pops to make them so vibrant should come with a warning: may turn your life delightfully strange. Though laughter is welcome, I doubt we’d have ended up on that fire escape, drinking beer in the howling wind, had we not eaten them earlier. Stumbling upon a closed bar’s doorway, we paused to flip through an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the mail. Lucky we did—who knew it held the deals of a lifetime? Certainly not me. A few highlights: buy 36 permanent markers, get a stunt kite. Purchase 30 lever arch files, score a barbecue.

Currently listening to: *The Little Drummer Boy* by Stevan Pasero... Now, onto my post. Senate Republicans—hands up, who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I know I didn’t. Well, fine, I tuned in briefly. This colossal waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans, furious that Democrats wouldn’t rubber-stamp four of Bush’s controversial judicial picks. They staged a multi-day spectacle to score political points, ignoring that Democrats have already confirmed 168 of Bush’s nominees. But no, that’s insufficient for power-hungry Republicans, who bizarrely believe they have a mandate for such theatrics.

This was a great weekend. I enjoyed a lot of God’s green leaf, and after a long time, I listened to Nevermore—something I should’ve started much earlier—while reading extensively. I finished three books: Bruce Sterling’s *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven’s *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler’s *Parable of the Sower*. *Heavy Weather* was an engaging cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future USA ravaged by climate chaos and anarchy. Though clever, well-paced, and convincingly written, I didn’t walk away with any profound impressions of the story or characters. Not that they weren’t well-crafted and vivid—it’s a good book, just not a masterpiece.

Because this is the aftermath. The first week back from practicum was a struggle, but only in the second week has the smoke truly begun to clear. Post-practicum trauma is a hidden epidemic now coming to light. I was overwhelmed, but meeting the course coordinator helped me unburden myself—preventing another student from enduring such a pedagogically deficient practicum school. Yesterday (Monday), I encountered another distressed classmate determined to warn the next student assigned to her school about how terrible it would be. I calmed her and suggested we approach the administrator first.

Fall 1974: I was attempting—for what felt like the 13th time—to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I despise math. I am math-phobic. You get the idea. As I struggled to grasp algebra, the doorbell rang. I set my book aside and answered the door. No one was there. Perfect. I returned to my studies, and just as a glimmer of understanding surfaced in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam—my breakthrough vanished. I checked the door once more, and again, no one. Just what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited prankster.

This past week has been exhausting. I spent Tuesday through Thursday moving to my new classroom. The room is larger and closer to my grade-level team, which are important factors as I prepare for the year. Had I known about the move earlier, I would have discarded unused books and supplies. Instead, everything came with me, so this week involved moving, unpacking, and extensive purging. I’m grateful to my teammate Jill for her help—she was still teaching in my old room this month, yet she and her wonderful students moved nearly everything for me!

You can’t escape it: a part of you will always live in me. Even if I never bore your child, even if we were never wed, even if we were never an official pair... I loved you deeply, and that feeling still echoes in my heart. I’ll forever cherish the few nights we shared, hearts and limbs entwined in a soulful embrace, bathed in the salty darkness of a beach evening... or a kiss in the rain. When a shard of darkness pierces my heart, you’ll be there—that piece of you, bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me... and lingers still.

"We had an outing yesterday with my colleagues from the bank. We visited Guintubdan, La Carlota—a first for most of us. The trek to the falls took about 30 minutes, leaving us breathless, but we persevered. The water was icy cold, numbing our bodies. We stayed briefly before heading to nearby waterfalls after another 30-minute hike. The effort was worth it—the falls were serene, and the scenery breathtaking. It felt like becoming one with nature. Soaking in the cold water was akin to communing with Mother Earth. The crisp air and chilling water were so soothing, they could lull you to sleep.

I’m sure my sisters are completely drunk. Today was Pride in San Diego, and I know them—when it’s time to drink, they go all out. It’s the one trait I didn’t inherit from the Buenviajes: the urge to drink. There are rare occasions when I don’t mind, but they’re few and far between. We have a month left before Ed leaves, and it’s starting to sink in for him—and for all of us. I realized it long ago. I just hope Ed stays for Bailey’s surgery. We’ve been monitoring his swelling, and there’s definitely quite a bit.

On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman’s Park, assuming the fireman’s Easter egg hunt started at 11 AM. Turns out, it was on Friday. Thankfully, I’d brought a bag of eggs just in case, so Connor still had a blast hunting for them in the park. Sunday morning, he woke up thrilled that the Easter Bunny had visited. Nothing beats seeing your child’s excitement. After the egg hunt, we attended church. While the Easter Bunny is fun, we ensure our kids understand the holiday’s true meaning. This was Megan’s first Easter—she looked adorable in her denim dress and stockings!

**Friday, November 22, 2002**  

Woohoo! My boots are at the house! I forgot and had them delivered there instead of work, so I have to wait four more hours to get them. Argh! These are the Face boots and Tredair Flame boots. I rock!  

Somehow, I managed to get a flat tire. Luckily, I’m at work, so the guys will inflate it and check if it holds air. If not, they’ll change the tire and put on the spare. Thankfully, my spare is full-sized. I might get a new tire tonight—woohoo! Hamad Tire, here I come!  

I thought I’d found another VW.

Music for the day: 94.7 FM. Almost didn’t make it to work on time—there’s a massive accident at 14th and Constitution, causing chaos in Virginia. Thankfully, I skillfully maneuvered from the far left lane to the far right and made it onto Route 50. Of course, this means nothing unless you live nearby...so never mind. Just glad to be here instead of stuck in my car.  

Yesterday, Sara googled me and found an email I wrote to Ivan Meisel on ESPN.com published online! Had no idea—didn’t think it was my best argument, but someone disagreed."

What can I say... *Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban* was absolutely brilliant!! I saw it right after school on Friday—yes, opening day! (Thanks, Mike, for the ticket.) Daniel Radcliffe, aka Harry Potter, has grown up so fast, and he’s adorable! Matthew too, haha. The movie was fantastic, though I’d give it 4½ stars since they left out key details. Overall, it was great! I didn’t dress up, but I wore a Ravenclaw tie—even though I prefer Gryffindor. Might see it again in a couple of weeks!

Pears and peanut butter attempt #2. This time, I have firm pears and my own jar of peanut butter for dipping—though it's crunchy, not smooth, which I think makes a difference. I’m slightly unsettled, having assumed this was a healthy snack, only to discover that per 100g (our jars are small), there are 614 calories! Best not to dwell on it. Just returned from an evening at my old music teacher’s house—yes, I missed her, but I recorded it! Also found out they’re airing repeats of series 9 every morning at 9:55. Seeing my friend was strange but nice.

The GOP faces criticism after recruitment efforts at naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville prompted relocation plans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the June 29 event appeared routine, with nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Before departing, an immigration official directed attendees to a voter registration table—a common practice. However, this table stood out: Republican volunteers distributed forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked, automatically enrolling new voters as GOP members. Linda Cross, present to witness her husband Dario Cruz’s oath, found the situation suspicious. Complaints about the GOP’s tactics led to the ceremonies being moved.

"So it’s not exactly hooky, but I’ve been accumulating sub-days and decided to use one today—Wednesday the 10th in Japan (the post-time shows the U.S. date, so it’s technically incorrect)—so I can relax for a couple of days. Nothing like 48 hours of daydreaming to recharge creatively. I’m fortunate as a foreigner, and my timing worked out well. The illustration gig is just the icing on the cake. I’d complain more if that hadn’t fallen into my lap. Still, I know I’m getting underpaid—I’m not blind to that. Getting hungry. Might grab Mexican food at Speakeasy, the ‘American-style’ diner across from the post office in my little prefecture.

I have always prided myself on making everyone who visits Casa Pescatore as comfortable as possible. I want them to feel at home, just as they would in their own residence. Yesterday—I hope I succeeded. The crowd gathered on Perry Ave with what many would call 'extreme prejudice.' At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, the food I prepared was ready, and the atmosphere was electric. Before I knew it, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, bringing an instant smile to my face. I’d missed him so much. The bonus? His wife joined him—she’s expecting, and this is the closest I’ll get to being an uncle. I spoiled her with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.

I liked the idea of that as an offense—perhaps it could've been a way to avoid being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I’ve hesitated to engage in certain discussions, especially those about flags. But since I brought up the topic (not flag-burning), I should probably weigh in. First, I believe outlawing flag-burning is absurd. The instant you grant a symbol—any symbol—automatic reverence and legal protection, you take a small but dangerous step toward totalitarianism. Symbols are fickle; they don’t inherently represent anything—their meaning lies in perception and imposed significance.

Okay, so I’m still unsure what my blog will look like, but this seems like the right place to start. I’m not entirely sure how it’ll unfold—whether I’ll stick with it or not—but since I spend so much time in front of a screen, I might as well put it to good use by sharing the whirlwind of thoughts bouncing around my mind. I was inspired by a blogger (whom I’ve never met), who kept readers engaged with intimate, day-to-day updates while also entertaining them along the way...

1. Everyone has a favorite movie or series—mine is the *Evil Dead* franchise. (In case it wasn’t obvious, I own one of the largest collections of memorabilia from the series.)  
2. Do you play an instrument? Bass guitar—and yes, I rock out.  
3. Biggest financial vice? Either compulsive DVD purchases or splurging on new tech.  
4. Any phobias, allergies, or compulsions? None, none, and I must arrange all bills in my wallet from smallest to largest.  
5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if it could? Because I said so.

Hey, so I watched *Troy* tonight with my family... and I wasn’t impressed. I’m too tired to dive into specifics, but it did have potential. Too much effort went into the set (which was stunning) and not enough into crafting a cohesive tone or theme. It retold the story but wasn’t gripping, and I didn’t feel enriched by it. The character development was weak. The score also fell flat, feeling like a *Gladiator* knock-off. *Gladiator* used a moaning woman’s vocals effectively—it complemented a compelling narrative, but here, it just felt out of place.

Ultracold 2D Fermi gases serve as pristine, tunable models to investigate the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, yet direct evidence of superfluidity has been elusive. Here, we observe superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and detecting no dissipation below a critical velocity \(v_{\rm c}\). We measure \(v_{\rm c}\) across interaction strengths and find a peak in the crossover between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. This result confirms ultracold Fermi gases as a versatile platform for exploring reduced dimensionality's role in strongly correlated superfluids.

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions comprising a time-reversal symmetry-broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) coupled to an $s$-wave superconductor. The differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes exhibit strong dependence on the angle between the junction direction and the momentum-space axis separating the Weyl nodes. We analyze how a chiral chemical potential—reflecting electron population imbalance between opposite-chirality Weyl nodes—affects junction transport. Notably, we detect a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in both WSM regions. This polarization is opposite in the two regions and highly sensitive to chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

We present a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, grounded in hidden local symmetry. The associated charge matches the skyrmion charge for smooth configurations, while singular configurations correspond to \( n_f=1 \) baryons charged under this symmetry. Here, vector mesons act as Chern-Simons fields on the quantum Hall droplet forming the baryon. We argue this current accurately represents the low-energy baryon current, unifying both baryon types and enabling natural transformations between them. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet arise from a Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions provides a fascinating platform to merge anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. We theoretically investigate how the interplay of these effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. Skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active interface generates significant transverse Hall supercurrents, termed anomalous Josephson Hall currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, originally developed to quantify conventional Josephson tunneling currents, to compute transverse current components and show their amplitudes can be widely tuned via spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference. As a spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions, localized subgap bound states emerge near the interface.

Following the suggestion from Monte Carlo experiments (Jiménez, J. Turbul. 2020) that dipoles are as dynamically significant as individual vortex cores in decaying two-dimensional turbulence, we find the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed from dipole concatenation. Vortices split into two families: small, fast-moving cores and larger, slow-moving ones, which appear "frozen" into a gradually evolving "crystal." Their kinematics differ markedly, with only the former being self-similar. The latter dominates the flow's kinetic energy, forming dipoles and streams. Mechanisms for the growth of this slow component are discussed.

Continuous-time quantum walks serve as a powerful framework for designing quantum algorithms. Typically, the runtime of such algorithms is determined by the quantum hitting time—the duration needed for the walk to locate a target vertex with high probability. In this article, we present enhanced upper bounds for quantum hitting times, applicable to various CTQW-based algorithms. Specifically, we apply these techniques to the glued-trees problem, reducing the hitting time upper bound from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$, a polynomial improvement. Additionally, our methods exponentially refine the precision dependence for the marked-node detection algorithm by Chakraborty et al., applicable to any ergodic, reversible Markov chain.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized as dry or wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously regarded as the primary sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, result from multi-body scattering in nuclear star clusters and gravitational capture. In this letter, we propose an alternative formation channel: wet EMRIs facilitated by accretion flows around galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). Here, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes on inclined orbits, driving their migration toward the MBH. This process enhances EMRI formation rates in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically lack information about them—no item interactions, no user profile, and no social connections. Despite this, we expect recommender systems to engage users immediately, encouraging them to stay and become active. This challenge, known as the new user cold-start problem, is critical for a company's growth and survival. Existing solutions either demand extra user effort (e.g., interviews) or rely on side information [10], such as demographics or social ties. However, users may resist interviews, and such side information is often unavailable for cold-start scenarios.

Deep learning has overcome challenges beyond heuristic algorithms and has proven effective in wireless communications, even with well-established radio systems and existing optimal solutions. While learning individual receiver components yields some improvements, jointly optimizing the entire receiver is more promising—though it often leads to complex nonlinear problems with impractical optimal solutions. To address this, we introduce **deeprx**, a deep fully convolutional neural network that processes the entire receiver pipeline, from frequency-domain signals to uncoded bits, in a 5G-compliant manner. By carefully structuring the CNN input with both data and pilot symbols, we enable precise channel estimation.

Mutation-based fuzzing relies on an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to generate new inputs through mutation. Often, a corpus contains thousands of similar inputs, and this lack of diversity can waste fuzzing effort by exhaustively mutating all seeds. To mitigate this, fuzzers include distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest seed subset triggering the same instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Minimizing seed count and cumulative size is widely believed to improve fuzzing efficiency, which we systematically investigate. We present findings from 34+ CPU-years of fuzzing using five distillation approaches to assess their impact on bug discovery in real-world software.

In this paper, we examine multi-agent discrete-event systems under partial observation. The agents can be grouped such that each group shares isomorphic state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into a common template. Using this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost remain unaffected by the number of agents, even under partial observation. This scalable supervisor does not require recomputation when agents are added or removed. We extend prior results to partial observation by establishing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the least restrictive scalable supervisor at the template level. An example demonstrates the proposed supervisory synthesis approach.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient ENF estimation method is introduced using temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. Leveraging the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix, a Gohberg-Semencul factorization is applied. Notably, this approach introduces—for the first time in ENF analysis—a non-rectangular temporal window prior to spectral estimation. Krylov matrices enable fast matrix inversion. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation, particularly with 1-second power recordings. For speech recordings, it achieves high accuracy while maintaining low computational complexity.

The **direpack** package introduces a collection of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into Python as a unified, consistent toolkit. The included methods fall into three categories: projection pursuit, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators. Additionally, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced spaces are provided, spanning from principal component regression to sparse partial robust M-regression. The package also offers classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with dedicated plotting and cross-validation tools. Designed to align with the scikit-learn API, **direpack** ensures seamless integration into statistical and machine learning pipelines.

"Nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely used for high-spatial-resolution optical imaging. Here, we investigated the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect in nitrogen-vacancy defects in diamond. Fluorescence reduction was observed under high-power laser excitation, enhancing emission nonlinearity and altering the spatial frequency distribution of fluorescence images. Using a differential excitation protocol, we extracted high-spatial-frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser power, imaging resolution improved by approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Given the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we anticipate this method will enhance spatial resolution in sensing and biological labeling applications using solid-state defects.

When random effects are correlated with design variables, standard methods using individual survey weights (inversely proportional to inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood fail to yield asymptotically unbiased inference. We propose a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that ensures unbiased hyperparameter estimation. Unlike frequentist methods relying on numerical integration, our Bayesian approach achieves both design-unbiased estimation and consistency with the population-generating distribution. Simulations and a business establishment survey demonstrate our method's versatility across models and sampling designs. This work culminates recent advances merging survey estimation with Bayesian modeling, bridging these two distinct yet powerful statistical domains.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS₂ and ReSe₂ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene—exhibit more complex atomic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. Their reduced symmetries lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, alongside novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, strong nonlinear optical effects, photogalvanic responses, and superconductivity. Additionally, low symmetry enables unique electronic topological traits, nonlinear elastic behavior, and structural phase transitions. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic showcases cutting-edge experimental and theoretical research on these materials.

The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was observed that, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of electric birefringence in a mesogenic polymer melt above the nematic-isotropic transition temperature can be described by multiple exponential processes, with two playing a dominant role. These primary processes alternate within a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy further revealed two orientational relaxation mechanisms: one arising from side-group rotation and the other linked to main-chain segment motion.

Deep hashing methods demonstrate strong retrieval accuracy and efficiency for large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in these methods. A common approach involves using activation functions like $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, coupled with minimizing quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this strategy may trap hash bits in incorrect saturated regions of the activation functions, preventing recovery—termed the "dead bits problem (dbp)." Additionally, existing quantization losses exacerbate dbp. To address this, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier applied before activation functions to mitigate dbp.

"We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry breaking. We examine scenarios where the triplet is either stable (contributing to dark matter) or decays via Higgs mixing. The stable case is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and direct detection experiments, while the decaying case faces limits from multilepton collider searches. Our analysis shows that a two-step phase transition with a stable triplet (having a negative quadratic term) is excluded by direct detection, whereas an unstable triplet below $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is ruled out at 95% confidence.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings around Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted by the standard eccentric planet perturbation model ("pericenter glow"). The model assumes an initially circular, narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis \(a\), whose eccentricity is raised to \(e_f\) via secular perturbations from an eccentric planet after gas disc dispersal, producing a belt of width \(2ae_f\). A slight modification suggests narrower belts could form if planetesimals were already eccentric, possibly due to earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary phase. Alternatively, primordial eccentricity might arise from disc instabilities, independent of planets.

An electron is typically considered to possess only one form of kinetic energy, but could it exhibit additional types due to its spin, charge, or interactions with other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model, yet experimental observations beyond this linear regime remain scarce. Here, we present measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using tunneling spectroscopy. We detect two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, linked to spin and charge excitations, along with three additional 1D "replica" modes that intensify as wire length decreases. The effective interaction strength in the wires is tuned by varying 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrent behaviors on a nanosecond scale, enabling promising spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Here, two physical RC systems—one based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and another using 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs)—were modeled for image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Micromagnetic simulations of MSM and STNO responses to current pulses demonstrate that an RC system with a single MSM achieves outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition. Moreover, a physical RC system comprising 24 STNOs effectively solves complex nonlinear dynamic problems, as confirmed by second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms are vital for online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. This paper reveals an unexpected outcome of popularity-based rankings: the fewer items sharing a signal, the greater their collective traffic share. This "few-get-richer" effect arises when items belong to limited distinct classes (e.g., left- vs. right-leaning news) and are ranked by popularity. We analytically show this occurs when users favor top-ranked items and exhibit heterogeneous class preferences. Through simulations, we examine how the effect's strength varies with contextual and behavioral assumptions. We also validate our predictions via an online experiment. These findings offer critical insights into misinformation spread.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as a simple yet effective method to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), enabling acceleration across platforms. However, most pruning techniques trade model accuracy for regularity, resulting in compromised inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration. To address this, we introduce pattern-based sparsity—a new dimension combining pattern and connectivity sparsity—delivering both high accuracy and hardware efficiency. Through carefully designed patterns, our pruning method consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction across diverse DNN architectures and datasets. Our framework simultaneously handles pattern library extraction, selection, pruning, and weight training. This approach naturally aligns with compiler optimizations, enabling efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that significantly differs from the treated group risks bias due to historical events affecting the groups differently. Creating a more closely matched control group—by selecting a subset of the overall controls—can reduce this bias. We examine this phenomenon through simulations. Specifically, we analyze the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences approach, leveraging the rise in MRM after the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For this analysis, we constructed a better-matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval spanning substantial adverse effects, no effect, and minor beneficial effects.

When building models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is essential to assess their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved using visual predictive checks (VPCs), which involve (1) simulating multiple replicates of the original study from the evaluated model, (2) computing key estimates for each simulated study, and (3) comparing their distribution with the original estimate. This approach is a versatile and generally straightforward method. Here, we explore its application to time-to-event data, particularly when a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated post-event.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. We demonstrate how similar protocols, combining repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in line with Zeno physics; (ii) analytically predict the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state via stochastic sequential measurements; and (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise by orthogonalizing frequency-domain filter functions for quantum sensors. These advancements will improve our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, driving progress in quantum science and technology.

When plants and organisms die, much of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants absorb it again. Volcanic eruptions release carbon trapped in rock, while human activities—such as burning fossil fuels—release prehistoric carbon. Today, humans emit roughly 60 times more carbon annually than all volcanoes combined.
